The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature. Love is one of the most common themes in art.
 
The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature. Love is one of the most common themes in art.
  +
An unfinished debate about the authenticity of love as other-regard began with Friedrich Nietzsche's charge that love is merely an ideology constructed by the weak to mask "resentment" about their lack of power. Critics of Nietzsche's view find gratuitous his assumptions that self-interest and the "will to power" overshadow all other concerns.
